Olive oil vs foie gras. Sensational Mediterranean diet study turns out to be erroneous
Olive oil vs foie gras - what will you choose? An unfortunate story befell the landmark scientific work that concerned the Mediterranean diet
02 Nov 2019, 05:22 by Andrey Semyankiv
Survival has always been and remains the main priority of mankind.
Over the past few years, homo sapiens has managed to significantly increase life expectancy and virtually eliminate the effects of biological factors such as hunger and fatal continental epidemics.
However, the number of causes that can lead to human death has paradoxically increased.
We are no longer bitten by wolves in the forests, however, the excessive amount of available food, and even more importantly its quality, turned out to be more dangerous than any natural predators.
Not surprisingly, any information about the effects of nutrition on health and life expectancy is always relevant. And every scientific research on this subject is rushed to be called ‚Äúsensational‚Äù by the media. And very often in vain.
An unfortunate story befell the iconic scientific work that concerned the Mediterranean diet.
This name refers to a diet that includes many vegetables, fruits, seafood and polyunsaturated fats (in the form of olive oil and nuts).
For about five years, this study was considered one of the most authoritative and fundamental. And no wonder, because more than 7000 people took part in it, who were divided into different research groups with different types of nutrition.
And those who consumed predominantly ‚ÄúMediterranean‚Äù foods as a result had a 30% lower risk of contracting cardiovascular disease. The findings of the study finally put an end to the debate about the healthiest diet.
At least it seemed so.
And in 2018, the New England Journal of Medicine, an authoritative medical journal in the world, was forced to withdraw the article.
Independent reviewers found flaws in the research procedure.
The fact is that the subjects had to be randomly assigned to different food groups.
It is this mechanism (randomization) that is designed to cut off other possible factors: for example, a lower genetic predisposition to heart disease among certain participants. And this would allow a more objective assessment of the impact of a diet.
However, the division was not always random. The Mediterranean diet was sometimes prescribed to whole families and towns.
Thus, although the benefits of this diet are obvious, there is no way to unequivocally state that it is this that causes a decrease in the frequency of certain diseases.
Finally, if we look at the epidemiological data of the European continent, we note that although the Mediterranean countries (Italy, Spain, Portugal, Greece) have a fairly low incidence of cardiovascular diseases, the inhabitants of France are the healthiest nation in this regard.
And we perfectly remember that various red meat, fatty pastes and pastries are national dishes there. That is, not the best products, in terms of vascular health.
Residents of the Netherlands die from cardiovascular disease as often as the Mediterranean Portuguese. And fans of cheese fondue in Switzerland suffer from coronary heart disease a little less than the Greeks.
Despite everything, the scientific search does not stop for a minute. Humanity is still in pursuit of that magical product that will finally give us health and longevity.
It is worth remembering that complex problems very rarely have simple solutions. Therefore, any sensational news in the style of "scientists finally determined ..." should be treated with caution.
